Comment: The STOCK Act is weaker than a lot of insider trading laws and provides fewer prosecutorial tools. Even when members of Congress are investigated under it there are not likely to be prosecutions (see: 2020).¬†   This is a legislative problem, which could be fixed by Congress.¬†   By contrast, the corruption of the Trump White House doesn't have a legislative fix because the DOJ won't enforce the law and SCOTUS has legalized bribery in all but the most extreme circumstances. Congress can't do much other than impeachment (which they won't do of course).¬†

Author: shanatard

Comment: It's a question of how the law defines material non public information and when someone acting on that information is considered an insider.¬†   The insider trading laws that apply to the officers of public companies don't apply to members of Congress any more that they apply to members of the public. Meaning members of Congress aren't considered "insiders" under the normal insider trading laws until they receive information from an insider.¬†   The STOCK Act was supposed to broaden these definitions to include information that members of Congress are privy to as legislators. The 2020 investigations related to congressional COVID briefings, for example.¬†   However these definitions did not go far enough, and members of Congress have too much latitude under existing law.   This means that even if DOJ did try to bring charges they would be unlikely to get a conviction. Whereas DOJ probably could get a conviction on a lot of the WH corruption if they were inclined to pursue it.¬†
Author: spleeble
